author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Adams Shows Support for Man Charged in Bodega Killing That Caused Outcry
description: A deadly confrontation at a Harlem store feeds a broader debate about crime and politics.
content: The chaotic scene inside a Harlem bodega began with a bag of chips and a declined electronic card transaction. It ended in death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: When Are Expired Drugs Truly Expired?
description: Plenty of us have medications that are past their expiration date. But are they still OK to use?
content: I don’t know about your medicine cabinet, but mine is a jumble of mostly expired drugs: the muscle relaxants I got when I threw out my back a few years ago; the anti-nausea medicine I never took during my stomach woes last summer; the Xanax to occasionally help me cope with the dizzying state of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Russia’s foreign minister is shunned, but not by all, at a G20 gathering.
description: Several Western officials declined to meet with Sergey V. Lavrov, and few agreed to even pose with him for customary photographs.
content: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — He was a skunk at the tropical resort party, shunned by many, though not by all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: High Court Sides With Prince Harry in Libel Claim
description: The initial ruling clears the way for Harry to pursue a libel claim against The Mail on Sunday over its reporting about his police protection.
content: LONDON — A judge in Britain ruled on Friday that parts of an article in a tabloid newspaper about Prince Harry’s fight with the government over police protection were defamatory, in an initial phase of Harry’s libel case against the paper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Waiting for a Slowdown
description: Plus: Elon Musk may be preparing for the next chapter in his Twitter takeover journey — court.
content: This morning, the Labor Department  reported that employers added 372,000 workers to their payrolls in June. Economists were expecting hiring to have slowed last month, as fewer workers are available or willing to take open jobs, and while consumer spending is slowing as higher interest rates, imposed by the Fed to combat inflation, take their toll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini Acquitted of Fraud
description: Blatter, the former president of FIFA, world soccer’s governing body, and Platini, his onetime ally, were charged over a $2 million payment that prosecutors had labeled a bribe.
content: Sepp Blatter, the former president of FIFA, and his onetime ally Michel Platini were acquitted of fraud on Friday in the latest attempt by Swiss prosecutors to win a conviction in a sprawling, seven-year investigation into corruption at the highest levels of world soccer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: When Power Dressing Gets Personal
description: Redefining the form at Jean Paul Gaultier, Fendi and Vetements.
content: PARIS — “Inclusivity, diversity, no gender binaries — he was the first one,” said Olivier Rousteing, otherwise known as the creative director of Balmain, ticking off the issues at the forefront of identity politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Emmy Rossum Dreams of Pink Macarons
description: The star and executive producer of “Angelyne” gets a master class at Ladurée.
content: “Look,” Emmy Rossum said, squeezing an excess of rose buttercream onto a waiting meringue. “We can’t all be perfect the first time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Can Lisa Murkowski Fend Off Kelly Tshibaka in Alaska?
description: Supporters of the senator hope that the state’s unique nonpartisan primary system will help her, but allies of Tshibaka, a Trump-backed challenger, see a path to victory.
content: Paulette Schuerch, a Native Alaskan who helped Lisa Murkowski’s fabled write-in campaign for Senate in 2010, is now working for the senator’s Trump-backed opponent, Kelly Tshibaka.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Can I Dress to Not Look Like a Tourist in France?
description: A reader is wondering what clothes to pack in her suitcase.
content: Once upon a time it was easy to spot Americans abroad (or so the cliché went, anyway): They were the loud ones in jeans and T-shirts with fanny packs and baseball caps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: The Pearls She’ll Never Wear
description: She bought the necklace when she was desperate. She lost it when she wasn’t.
content: Eliza Smith was only 18 when she found herself back with her ex-boyfriend and, then, unintentionally pregnant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Sheet-Pan Chicken Recipe for Lovers of Sweet and Savory
description: Roasted chicken thighs are paired with tangy sour cherries and finished with a creamy, cooling cucumber yogurt in this balanced weeknight meal.
content: Every July, I question my sour cherry priorities. Their season is so short, and the fruit so scarce that I rarely get around to making anything beyond one big, gushy pie and a year’s supply of homemade maraschino cherries (must-haves in my manhattan cocktail).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Larry Storch, Comic Actor Best Known for ‘F Troop,’ Dies at 99
description: His well-honed comic timing, and the mimicry skills he had developed in nightclubs, served him well on one of the sillier sitcoms of the 1960s.
content: Larry Storch, who played a memorable television oddball on the 1960s sitcom “F Troop” and for years carried a secret in his personal life that was odd in an entirely different way, died on Friday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: At Europe’s Largest Port, Russia Sanctions Meet Their Toughest Test
description: The Dutch port of Rotterdam and its staff are at the front line of enforcing the European Union’s restrictions on trade with Russia. It’s no easy task.
content: ROTTERDAM, Netherlands — Jolanda Wielenga was checking documents accompanying containers bound for Russia when her heart skipped a beat: One held a substance that could be used to make a chemical weapon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: U.S. Qualifies for 2023 Women’s World Cup
description: A lopsided victory over Jamaica in a regional championship ensured that the Americans would get to defend their World Cup title next summer.
content: A United States women’s national team that arrived in Mexico this week with two objectives has already achieved the first: After a lopsided victory over Jamaica on Thursday night, the United States clinched a place in the 2023 Women’s World Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: An Interview With San Francisco’s New District Attorney
description: Brooke Jenkins, who helped lead the recall of her predecessor Chesa Boudin, will be sworn in on Friday.
content: A month after San Francisco voters ousted their progressive district attorney, Chesa Boudin, the city has a new top cop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Glimpses of Brittney Griner Show a Complicated Path to Release
description: The W.N.B.A. star’s appearances this week during her trial on drug charges in Russia highlighted the unclear path to her release and heightened her supporters’ concerns for her safety.
content: One hundred forty-one days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Kenward Elmslie, Poet and Librettist, Dies at 93
description: He collaborated on operas with Jack Beeson and Ned Rorem and published numerous poetry books. Late in life, he was victimized by theft.
content: Kenward Elmslie, who wrote poetry, opera librettos and stage musicals, and who late in life made headlines when his chauffeur bilked him out of millions of dollars and several valuable artworks, including one by Andy Warhol, died on June 29 at his home in the West Village. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic vs. Nick Kyrgios Makes for a Villainous Wimbledon Final
description: Kyrgios is playing in his first Grand Slam singles final, and Djokovic may be playing in his last until next year’s French Open.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — In the last year, Novak Djokovic has experienced the highest of tennis highs, coming within one match of winning a rare calendar-year Grand Slam and the lowest of lows, including detainment and deportation after he arrived in Melbourne in January to try to defend his Australian Open title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan, Isabella Kwai and Carly Olson
title: BA.4 and BA.5 power a surge of known infections in Europe, officials say.
description: While many European countries have seen an uptick in hospitalizations, “what we’re not seeing is an increase in intensive care unit admissions, so the vaccines are still very much working,” an official with the World Health Organization said this week.
content: The rapidly spreading Omicron subvariants known as BA.4 and BA.5 are driving a summertime surge of the coronavirus in Europe, health officials say, after most Covid policies were removed in spring and a more relaxed approach to the pandemic has become the norm during the warmer months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson Hasn’t Left, but the Jockeying to Replace Him Has Begun
description: The Conservative Party must decide not only who should succeed the scandal-tarred British prime minister, but also when he should go.
content: LONDON — On the surface, it looked like business as usual at the heart of British government on Friday, a day after Boris Johnson was forced to announce he would resign as prime minister when his party turned against him over the latest in a series of embarrassing scandals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Aggeler
title: What Happens When a Rock Star Proposes Onstage?
description: Olivia Jean married the celebrated musician Jack White mid-performance, but she has a plan all her own.
content: It was something out of a fairy tale, if everyone in fairy tales wore denim and leather and looked like they smoked American Spirits. One minute, Olivia Jean was a shy kid from Michigan competing in her school’s battle of the bands show, and the next, she’s performing with her boyfriend, the musician Jack White, and he’s proposing to her in the middle of his song “Hotel Yorba” — right before the line “Let’s get married/ In a big cathedral by a priest.” A minute later, Mr. White remembered, come to think of it, one of the guys backstage was a licensed minister — does she want to get married right then?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: What a New Supreme Court Review May Mean for Albany’s Culture of Graft
description: Joseph Percoco and Alain Kaloyeros, former aides to Andrew Cuomo, could benefit if the court is more skeptical of what constitutes corruption.
content: Joseph Percoco and his taste for “ziti.” Alain Kaloyeros, the flashy tech executive convicted in a fraud. Joseph Bruno and a no-good racehorse named Christy’s Night Out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Divisions over the war play out at a G20 meeting as Russia prepares for an assault on Donetsk in eastern Ukraine.
description: As foreign ministers from the Group of 20 industrialized nations met in Bali on Friday to discuss some of the world’s most pressing challenges, including the war in Ukraine, the divisions playing out as a result of the fighting were to the fore diplomatically, too.
content: As foreign ministers from the Group of 20 industrialized nations met in Bali on Friday to discuss some of the world’s most pressing challenges, including the war in Ukraine, the divisions playing out as a result of the fighting were to the fore diplomatically, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: What the Biden Administration Could Do Now to Protect Abortion Rights
description: The most urgent step the federal government can take is to ensure access to medication abortion.
content: Barely two weeks have passed since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, and already chaos reigns. Several states are moving to ban abortion almost completely, abortion-rights proponents are challenging those bans in court and in some cases, judges have been asked to issue injunctions that could, for a time, prevent the bans from going into effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: For Sunday’s Wimbledon Final, ‘Fireworks’ and a Contrast in Style
description: Despite their previously contentious relationship, Nick Kyrgios and Novak Djokovic have developed “a bit of a bromance,” Kyrgios said. They meet for the Wimbledon men’s singles title on Sunday.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — With the Wimbledon title at stake, it will be the maximizer versus the man who seemingly makes it up as he goes along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Ben Dooley and Hikari Hida
title: Assassination Shocks a Nearly Gun-Free Japan
description: Stringent rules on gun ownership had all but eradicated gun violence in the country.
content: The assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe during a campaign rally in western Japan was especially hard to fathom because it involved a gun — a type of crime that is extremely rare in a country with some of the most stringent laws on buying and owning firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The power, and limits, of local action
description: In the absence of national climate measures in the United States, how much can be done at the local level? Our reporters talk about the opportunities and barriers.
content: The White House can’t get climate legislation passed. Congress is gridlocked. The Supreme Court has tied the hands of the federal agency entrusted to protect the environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Boris Johnson Leaves a Mixed Legacy With His Brexit Gambit
description: Departure from E.U. is a clear negative for the U.K. economy, but it could have been worse.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson will be remembered for Britain’s exit from the European Union long after the world has forgotten the tousled hair, the quotations in Homeric Greek, the fibs, fabrications and scandals — not to mention the time he got stuck on a zip line while serving as London mayor, sheepishly waving Union Jacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Russia Votes to Shut Down Last U.N. Aid Route Into Syria
description: Millions of Syrians whose lives have already been shattered by more than a decade of war may be left without food, medicine and other supplies.
content: WASHINGTON — Russia vetoed a measure on Friday that would have allowed the last U.N. aid route into Syria to remain open for another year, in a vote that diplomats and critics said endangered the lives of millions of people already suffering after more than a decade of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How Dan Perlman, of ‘Flatbush Misdemeanors,’ Spends His Sundays
description: After singing lessons and some basketball, the actor, who is “easing back into standup,” stops by a few comedy clubs.
content: The Showtime comedy “Flatbush Misdemeanors” was originally a low-budget web series created by Dan Perlman and Kevin Iso, two comics who had met at open mic events around the city. Now the show, about two friends struggling to get by in Flatbush, Brooklyn, is into its second season. Mr. Perlman, 32, who is also an executive producer of the series, lives in a one-bedroom apartment in, you guessed it, Flatbush.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Dangerous Liaisons’ Review: The Epistolary Novel as Instagram Feed
description: A new film adaptation brings Pierre Choderlos de Laclos’s 1782 book to the halls of a high school in modern-day France.
content: First published in 1782, Pierre Choderlos de Laclos’s wicked romp of a novel, “Dangerous Liaisons,” requires only a light airbrush to be convincingly transplanted to the halls of a modern-day high school where teenagers wield sex, power and status like weapons. Nevertheless, the director Rachel Suissa runs Laclos’s story through a heavy Instagram filter in this outlandish, flimsy adaptation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The U.S. May Be Losing the Fight Against Monkeypox, Scientists Say
description: Longstanding weaknesses in the public health system are giving the virus a chance to become entrenched.
content: As epidemics go, the monkeypox outbreak should have been relatively easy to snuff out. The virus does not spread efficiently except through intimate contact, and tests and vaccines were at hand even before the current outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Besonen
title: Windswept Views and ‘Glories Strung Like Beads’: Exploring Brooklyn by Ferry
description: More than 160 years after Walt Whitman extolled the joys of riding the ferry, there are fresh opportunities to explore neighborhoods like Red Hook, Brooklyn Heights and Bay Ridge by boat.
content: Looking for a fresh way to scout Brooklyn’s waterfront? Try a ferry. For $2.75, you can explore ports of call that cradle a bounty of cultural and culinary adventures. Island-hopping from Manhattan can begin at the Pier 11-Wall Street landing, where the salty air is invigorating and anticipation builds as vessels with names like Ferry Godmother, City Fishy and McShiny pull in to whisk you away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: With Roe Overturned, Austin’s Loss Could Be Brooklyn’s Gain
description: Cities around the South have challenged the supremacy of coastal supercities, drawing a steady flow of creative young people. Will new abortion bans put an end to that?
content: Imagine that you are a young woman setting out on your adult life in the United States of America in 2022. College is behind you; fulfilling personal and professional ambitions in a stimulating place is meant to come next. Ten or 20 years ago, depending on your interests, you might have moved, as if by reflex, to New York or Chicago, to Los Angeles or San Francisco. But those cities have become only more punishingly expensive. The average rental price of an apartment in Brooklyn is now $3,500, up 12 percent over last year, when we were still lingering in the misguided belief that the pandemic had perhaps changed the city irrevocably toward the softer and more accessible. (In Manhattan, the figure jumped 32 percent to $4,800.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Rabasca Roepe
title: Start-Up Equity Is a Great Retirement Plan, if You Can Pull It Off
description: Many employees of start-ups are attracted to the prospect of a big payout and an early retirement, but the strategy can require more luck than skill.
content: Nearly two years ago, Trevor Ford left a job at LendingTree that gave him a 401(k) plan and a generous employer match to work at Yotta, an online banking app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Peyser
title: Where Bobbleheads Are Born
description: The Licensing Expo returned in person this year, where characters big and small searched for a match made in consumer heaven.
content: At 10:30 a.m. on the second day of the annual Licensing Expo in Las Vegas, mascots from a wide variety of beloved brands lined up by a small stage in the back of the convention center at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, preparing to march around for a character parade. Sonic the Hedgehog was there, as were several Teletubbies, a Smurf, Peppa Pig, the Elf on the Shelf and Geoffrey, the Toys “R” Us giraffe. Also in attendance: a Dole pineapple with huge eyes and supple pink lips, and a Dole banana who looked very happy, but lacked the pout of its pineapple friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Divided Ukrainians
description: Residents in Sloviansk are far from united as they brace for a Russian onslaught.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Twitter is ready for a legal battle to force Elon Musk to buy the company.
description: Mr. Musk has appeared reluctant to proceed with the $44 billion agreement, citing uncertainty about the number of fake accounts on the platform.
content: [Follow for updates as Elon Musk has said he plans to terminate his $44 billion deal to buy Twitter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: Momix’s ‘Alice’ Is a Rabbit Hole (or 22) Too Far
description: Momix’s latest show, now at the Joyce Theater, is inspired by Lewis Carroll’s “Alice in Wonderland.”
content: The dance critic Edwin Denby once wrote, “Daily life is wonderfully full of things to see.” That observation came to mind on Thursday during Momix’s “Alice,” a banal and busy 85-minute spectacle now at the Joyce Theater. Not that anything particularly wondrous was going on; quite the opposite. At that point in the show, the thought of simply stepping outdoors into the city night — to look at traffic, or the sunset, or people in the streets — was more enticing than any fantasy depicted onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hikari Hida and Hisako Ueno
title: Assassination Rattles Peaceful Japan
description: The violence shook the country’s sense of identity as a peaceful country where violent crime is rare. “This is so not Japanese.”
content: The stunning assassination of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe rattled Japan and its sense of identity as a peaceful country where violent crime is rare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez and Ashley Wu
title: Everyday Violence
description: We look at where most of America’s gun violence happens.
content: Since a gunman killed seven people at a Chicago suburb’s July 4 parade, more than 160 people have died from other gun homicides across the country. In Chicago alone, at least 10 people were killed in multiple shootings during the holiday weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Families of civilian soldiers worry and wait in Ukraine.
description: Many of the fighters have no previous military experience.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — As thousands of young men and women are deployed to the front lines in Ukraine, each leaves behind family members and friends who hold their collective breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Secret Service Director to Step Down and Join Maker of Snapchat
description: The director, James M. Murray, was appointed by President Donald J. Trump in 2019 and is departing after nearly three decades with the agency.
content: WASHINGTON — The director of the Secret Service announced on Thursday that he would retire at the end of the month after a 27-year career with the agency that is charged with protecting the president of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Joyce C. Lashof, Doctor Who Shattered Glass Ceilings, Dies at 96
description: In Illinois, she was the first woman to head a state public health department. She went on to become dean of the School of Public Health at Berkeley.
content: Dr. Joyce C. Lashof, who fought for health equity and broke barriers as the first woman to head a state public health department and the first to serve as dean of the School of Public Health at the University of California, Berkeley, died on June 4 at an assisted living community in Berkeley. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a romantic do-over, two-minute time travelers and unwanted party guests.
content: Time travel and romance make for a good cinematic combination because we just want to believe that true love is out there, even if you need a temporal do-over or three to finally secure it. In Greg Björkman’s assured debut feature, Laura (Clara Rugaard, from “I Am Mother”) and Harrison (Lewis Pullman, “Top Gun: Maverick”) meet, argue about the band Japanese Breakfast and fall in love. Then a car hits him and he dies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick and Hurubie Meko
title: What’s Next for Abortion Rights in New York?
description: Before Roe v. Wade, New York City was a haven for women from across the country. Decades later, a new generation of advocates has vowed that it will remain so.
content: New York has long been at the forefront of the push for abortion access. The state legalized the procedure three years before the Supreme Court decided Roe v. Wade in 1973. Thousands of women flooded in from other states, soon outnumbering the number of New York residents getting abortions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: How Could This Be Murder?
description: In Tom Mead’s “Death and the Conjuror,” a man is found dead in his study, his throat cut. There is no weapon in the room, and the doors are locked — from the inside.
content: I’ve enjoyed the recent miniboom in locked-room mysteries, though I am starting to wonder if the number of “impossible crime” plots are finite. (I’ll add that any crime novel comparing itself to “And Then There Were None” or the film “Knives Out” must meet an exceedingly high threshold.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Before Heading to College, Make a Mental Health Checklist
description: Students should not wait until they are on campus to begin thinking about how to protect their emotional well-being, experts say.
content: As fall approaches, new students will arrive on college campuses toting all kinds of things: luggage and school supplies, mini fridges and sports equipment. But in the midst of the preparation for move-in day, many have not considered what tools they will need to support themselves emotionally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Man Who Swung Bat at Squeegee Workers in Baltimore Is Fatally Shot
description: The man, who had a heated confrontation with the workers as he drove through a downtown intersection, parked his car, approached the group with a baseball bat and swung it at them, the police said.
content: A man who got out of his car and swung a bat at squeegee workers during a confrontation in downtown Baltimore was killed Thursday when one of the workers pulled out a gun and shot him, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: For Ukraine, Boris Johnson’s Resignation Means Loss of a Personal Ally
description: Boris Johnson may be a polarizing figure in Britain, but in Ukraine he is widely adored for his unstinting support since the conflict with Russia.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson may be a polarizing figure in Britain, where his long association with scandal rendered him a lonely man this week as scores of onetime political allies abandoned him, forcing his resignation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Putting the Public Back in Public Service
description: A group of academics and lawmakers, citing a new study that found voters feel shut out of congressional deliberations, is pushing to engage citizens more directly in the work of Congress.
content: WASHINGTON — One of the most vexing questions about the dysfunction of Congress is why lawmakers cannot find common ground on big issues facing the country when convincing data suggests there is broad public consensus about what should be done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Rockets, Feathers and Prices at the Pump
description: Yes, market power can worsen inflation.
content: One of the sad paradoxes of politics is that few economic indicators matter more for public opinion — for voters’ evaluation of the government in power — than energy prices, especially the price of gasoline. This isn’t just a U.S. phenomenon: Inflation driven by soaring energy prices has undermined the popularity of leaders across the Western world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: From Sad Leftovers to Dream Dinners
description: Five recipes for the use-them-or-lose-them ingredients hanging out in your refrigerator.
content: This is Priya Krishna, your replacement captain for this week’s Five Weeknight Dishes. The Priya you see today has come a long way in the kitchen. My young, new-to-New York self had a simple but cost-effective weeknight cooking strategy: Buy the same few ingredients every week (pasta, spinach, tomatoes, feta, frozen dumplings, sausage, yogurt), throw a surprise item (sweet potatoes! cookie butter ice cream! an avocado!) into the cart, and make it all work with the rest of my pantry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: A Fresh Start on the Mountain That Changed Her Life
description: Reggie Clark and Jamie MoCrazy met in 2017, two years after she suffered a traumatic brain injury during a skiing competition on Whistler Mountain. In May, they returned to marry.
content: Reggie Clark and Jamie MoCrazy were immediately drawn to each other after meeting through a mutual friend in June 2017 at a Bar Named Sue near Salt Lake City, where he lived. They bonded over a shared love for the outdoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: At Ballet Theater, Visions of the Natural World and ‘Swan’ Debuts
description: Catherine Hurlin makes a major debut as Odette-Odile and the company presents the New York premiere of a mystical work by Alonzo King.
content: American Ballet Theater’s “Swan Lake,” which wrapped up its performances at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday, can feel choppy, as if its swans were pushing through water that becomes rougher with each passing year. This production, from 2000, was staged by Kevin McKenzie, who will soon retire as Ballet Theater’s artistic director. Is it time for his “Swan Lake” to leave the company, too? Alexei Ratmansky, the artist in residence, has a jewel of a “Swan Lake” in his back pocket, already made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 5: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by July 15 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 26.
content: Welcome to Week Five of our 13th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Michelle Goldberg Grapples With Feminism After Roe
description: The Times Opinion columnist considers the current backlash against feminism — and where the movement goes next.
content: “It’s true: We’re in trouble,” writes Michelle Goldberg of the modern feminist movement. “One thing backlashes do is transform a culture’s common sense and horizons of possibility. A backlash isn’t just a political formation. It’s also a new structure of feeling that makes utopian social projects seem ridiculous.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pasick
title: Losing the fight against monkeypox
description: A troubling replay of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The monkeypox outbreak should have been relatively easy to snuff out. The virus does not spread efficiently except through intimate contact, and tests and vaccines were at hand before the current outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Shinzo Abe, Japan’s Longest-Serving Prime Minister, Dies at 67
description: Mr. Abe was shot on Friday during a campaign event. Before he left office in 2020, he helped pull his country out of economic malaise but fell short of his most cherished goal: to normalize Japan’s military after decades of postwar pacifism.
content: Shinzo Abe, the longest-serving Japanese prime minister, who made it his political mission to vanquish his country’s wartime ghosts but fell short of his ultimate goal of restoring Japan as a normalized military power, was assassinated on Friday in the city of Nara, Japan. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Michelle Goldberg
description: The July 8, 2022 episode of ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Michelle Goldberg. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Alina Lobzina
title: Russia sentences a lawmaker to seven years in prison for denouncing the war.
description: The Russian authorities have opened dozens of similar cases since the government made denouncing the war a crime, but Aleksei Gorinov was the first to receive a substantial prison term for it.
content: A court in Moscow on Friday sentenced an opposition lawmaker to seven years in prison for denouncing Russia’s war in Ukraine, handing down the first prison term for what the government made a crime shortly after the invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Valerie Hopkins and Jane Arraf
title: For foreign fighters, the war is unlike any they’ve seen.
description: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Four months after Russia invaded Ukraine, foreign combat veterans who answered the Ukrainian president’s call to fight are grappling with the grueling reality of a war unlike any they have seen.
content: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Four months after Russia invaded Ukraine, foreign combat veterans who answered the Ukrainian president’s call to fight are grappling with the grueling reality of a war unlike any they have seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Next Time Trump Tries to Steal an Election, He Won’t Need a Mob
description: Conservatives want to give state legislatures the power to overturn presidential elections, but their case is built on a fundamentally flawed premise.
content: Last week, the Supreme Court announced it would hear arguments in Moore v. Harper, a challenge to North Carolina’s new congressional map.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Compatible Phone Charger Led to a Strong Connection
description: Amina Colter and Jason Jones became long-distance pals after he lent her his phone charger during a teen weekend. They began dating 12 years later.
content: When Amina Elise Colter walked into Barcelona Wine Bar 45 minutes late and sat down for her first date with Jason Michael Jones, he sensed that his waitress and nearby tables wanted to cheer. And so did he.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: José Eduardo dos Santos, Longtime Angolan Ruler, Dies at 79
description: As Angola’s president for 38 years, Mr. dos Santos ended the country’s civil war. He also launched an economic boom, but it mainly benefited his family and friends.
content: José Eduardo dos Santos, a onetime Soviet-trained fighter against Portuguese colonial rule who in nearly four decades as Angola’s president became one of Africa’s longest-serving rulers — and was also accused of corruption on a grand scale — died on Friday in Barcelona, Spain, where he had been living in self-imposed exile. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Jin Yu Young
title: Even in Death, Internet Explorer Lives On in South Korea
description: Why a country known for blazing broadband and innovative devices remains tethered to a browser that most of the world abandoned long ago.
content: SEOUL — In South Korea, one of the world’s most technologically advanced countries, there are few limits to what can be done conveniently online — except if you’re using the wrong web browser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and McKenna Oxenden
title: ‘Why Is Everyone Wearing Suits?’: #GentleMinions Has Moviegoers Dressing Up
description: A TikTok trend around the release of “Minions: The Rise of Gru” has young people around the globe suiting up for the cinema.
content: Normally when Carson Paskill heads to the movie theater, he opts for a comfortable outfit of sweatpants and a sweatshirt. But last weekend, he arrived in a black suit, white collared shirt and dress shoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: Codependency Is a Toxic Myth in Addiction Recovery
description: Love doesn’t enable addiction.
content: With over seven million copies sold, Melody Beattie’s 1986 best seller, “Codependent No More: How to Stop Controlling Others and Start Caring for Yourself,” is considered a self-help classic and continues to sell well in a new 2022 edition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Dolnick and An Rong Xu
title: He Had a Dark Secret. It Changed His Best Friend’s Life.
description: Tin Chin and Mo Lin were inseparable at the homeless shelter. But one of the men wasn’t who he seemed to be.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Shao
title: Biodiversity Crisis Affects Billions Who Rely on Wild Species, Researchers Say
description: The latest global assessment of the decline in plant and animal life found some bright spots but recommended significant changes to hunting and other practices to address the risks.
content: Billions of people worldwide rely on some 50,000 wild species for food, energy, medicine and income, according to a sweeping new scientific report that concluded humans must make dramatic changes to hunting and other practices to address an accelerating biodiversity crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: Rhea Seehorn Is Getting Away With It
description: The jig is up for Kim Wexler as “Better Call Saul” nears a close. Meanwhile, the actress who plays her has been quietly stealing the show.
content: LOS ANGELES — Rhea Seehorn insists she is a rule follower. And not the kind who, like her character Kim Wexler on AMC’s “Better Call Saul,” follows some rules in public while bending others in secret to whatever ends she believes are just.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan DiTrolio
title: Covering a Pre- and Post-Roe World
description: Margot Sanger-Katz, a domestic correspondent who writes about health care for The Upshot, shares how previous reporting helped readers understand the future of abortion access in the United States.
content: In July 2019, The Upshot, an arm of The New York Times that focuses on data-driven journalism, published the article “Where Roe v. Wade Has the Biggest Effect.” Written by the journalists Margot Sanger-Katz, Claire Cain Miller and Quoctrung Bui, the article examined what would happen if Roe v. Wade was to be overturned — Where would the number of legal abortions fall? What might happen in states with so-called trigger laws, which would ban abortion almost immediately? Using research, it estimated what could happen under various scenarios, and with maps, displayed what at that point was an alternate reality.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: He Charms, Lies and Blusters: It Always Saved Him, Till Now
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 8, 2022.
content: “People have known that Boris Johnson lies for 30 years. He’s probably the best liar we’ve ever had as a prime minister. He knows a hundred different ways to lie.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: At BroadwayCon, Hillary Clinton Celebrates Women in the Theater
description: The former secretary of state moderated a discussion on Friday afternoon about successes and barriers for women working in the theater.
content: “There’s a lot to worry about right now in our country and the world,” Hillary Clinton, the former secretary of state, told a packed room of about 500 people gathered at the grand ballroom at the Manhattan Center on Friday afternoon. “And I think we need theater and the arts more than ever.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sasani and Kate Zernike
title: Louisiana Judge Allows Abortion Ban to Take Effect
description: The fast-changing status in the state is emblematic of the chaotic national landscape that has unfolded in the two weeks since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.
content: A judge in Louisiana allowed state laws banning nearly all abortions to take effect on Friday, lifting an earlier court decision that had temporarily blocked them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Russia’s Lavrov Is Pariah at Group of 20 Event, but Only for Some
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and other Western foreign ministers refused to meet with the Russian diplomat, but for many others it was business as usual.
content: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — He was like a skunk at the tropical resort party, shunned by many, though by no means all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Bissell
title: How to Design a Beautiful, Cruel Universe
description: Gabrielle Zevin’s novel “Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow” is a love letter to the Literary Gamer.
content: Most kids who play a lot of video games don’t grow up to become avid readers. Then again, not every kid who reads a lot of books grows up to become an avid reader. Yet, in the diverse taxonomy of the modern gaming audience, there exists the Literary Gamer — someone for whom reading and playing are, and always have been, the same voyage. It would never occur to the Literary Gamer that one activity negates the other. If anything, the Literary Gamer believes, reading and playing enhance systematic thinking and the mysteries of imaginative empathy. This reviewer, for better or worse, is an avowed Literary Gamer — and I call upon my brothers and sisters to join me in a recitation of  Fünke’s Axiom: “There are dozens of us! DOZENS!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: At the Opera, Humans Bear Witness to Atrocity, or Ignore It
description: Whether in works by Mahler, Mozart or Rossini, directors at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France evoke mass death and refugee crises.
content: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — The bodies kept coming up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Why the Overturning of Roe Won’t Lead to a Return of Segregation
description: A constitutional slippery slope wouldn’t take the Supreme Court toward revisiting the 1964 Civil Rights Act.
content: Now that the Supreme Court, with its ruling in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, has struck down Roe v. Wade, many have argued that the court might begin diminishing or doing away with other expansions of constitutional rights. Much of the reaction traces to Justice Clarence Thomas, who in his concurring opinion in Dobbs argued that “In future cases, we should reconsider all of this Court’s substantive due process precedents, including Griswold, Lawrence and Obergefell.” It was a shot across the legal bow that prompted James Obergefell, one of the petitioners in Obergefell v. Hodges — the case that guaranteed same-sex couples a constitutional right to marry — to respond, in an interview on CNN last week, that Thomas had “put a target” on “the right to contraception, the right to intimacy with the person you love and the right to marry the person you love,” and “that should terrify everyone in this nation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: 9 James Caan Movies to Stream
description: Drama, comedy, suspense, action, kids’ movies — there was truly nothing he couldn’t do. Who else could star in both “The Godfather” and “Elf”?
content: When James Caan’s family announced his death on Thursday, it sent shock waves through cinematic circles — not because his passing was particularly premature (he was 82), but because he seemed such a vibrant and outsize personality, you figured he just might live forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: U.S. Economy Added 372,000 Jobs in June, Defying Slowdown Fears
description: The strong Labor Department report comes as consumers and businesses express increasing concern about a downturn.
content: The U.S. economy powered through June with broad-based hiring on par with recent months, keeping the country clear of recession territory even as inflation eats into wages and interest rates continue to rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Start Investing Early and Stick With It, Especially When Stocks Fall
description: A bear market can be great for your future wealth, if you use broad, low-cost funds to buy stocks and bonds steadily for decades, our columnist says.
content: I wouldn’t wish this bear market on anyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: In ‘The Bear’ on Hulu, a Kitchen Staff Is Nearly Eaten Alive
description: The new FX television show is one of the most vivid, authentic portrayals of what it’s like to work in food service.
content: Movies and TV shows about the inner workings of the culinary world have let us peek into restaurant kitchens before. But FX’s new “The Bear” is the first to force you to work in one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz and Francesca Jones
title: The Robot Guerrilla Campaign to Recreate the Elgin Marbles
description: The British Museum has staunchly refused to return the Parthenon Marbles to Greece. A team of archaeologists are working on a technological solution to the dispute.
content: Few cultural disputes inflame British passions more than the disposition of the Parthenon Marbles. Public debate about the statuary has raged since the early 1800s, when the sculptures and bas-reliefs, which date from 447 B.C. to 432 B.C., were stripped from the Parthenon and other Classical Greek temples on the Acropolis of Athens by agents of Thomas Bruce, a Scottish statesman and seventh earl of Elgin. The marbles were purchased — some say looted — by Elgin during his time as ambassador to the Ottoman Empire, the occupying power; they have resided in the British Museum since 1817.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Wisconsin Supreme Court Prohibits the Use of Most Drop Boxes for Voting
description: The ruling by the court, which has a narrow conservative majority, comes as Republicans have tried to limit voting access in the state’s cities.
content: The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Friday prohibited the use of most drop boxes for voters returning absentee ballots, giving the state’s Republicans a major victory in their efforts to limit voting access in urban areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Susie Steiner, Author of Acclaimed British Crime Novels, Dies at 51
description: Her books found a worldwide audience, but while she wrote them she had to contend with the loss of her sight and the diagnosis of a brain tumor.
content: Susie Steiner, the author of the critically acclaimed Manon Bradshaw detective novels, who was declared legally blind from a rare disease months before she sold her first book, died on July 2 in London. She was 51.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Director of the Guggenheim to Step Down
description: Richard Armstrong, whose 14-year tenure was shaped by staff complaints of racism, labor issues and a public outcry over a planned offshoot in Abu Dhabi, said he will leave the museum in 2023.
content: Richard Armstrong, the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, said he planned to retire from his role next year, capping off more than 14 years leading the institution and its international offshoots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Wages climbed 5.1 percent, a still-rapid pace as Fed awaits slowdown.
description: Central bankers are closely watching wage growth, which has been picking up rapidly before accounting for inflation.
content: Wages continued to climb rapidly last month, offering little encouragement to the Federal Reserve as policymakers hope for a slowdown in pay gains that might allow inflation to moderate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randy Kennedy
title: A Self-Taught Artist Takes His Roadside Acropolis North
description: Outside the art establishment for decades, Charles Smith has sculpted his Black heroes in Aurora, Ill., and now in Hammond, La. At 81, he’s getting his first show in New York.
content: HAMMOND, La. — Along Interstate 55 heading to this small town north of New Orleans, you pass several signs telling you what’s ahead, literally and maybe also metaphorically: Ponchatoula Antique City, Tickfaw State Park, Don’s Seafood, Apocalypse Sports (“Guns, Ammo, Tactical.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Smith
title: Losing the Pregnancy, the Marriage and the Pearls
description: At 18, I didn’t want to be the captain of my own fate. Fourteen years later, I do, and am.
content: My first job after college was as a seasonal sales associate at Macy’s in my hometown of Joplin, Mo. I had already worked there on two separate occasions before moving away for school. Now I was back, invariably ducking behind jewelry displays to avoid being spotted by old classmates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Three Tales From the Transfer Market
description: Cristiano Ronaldo’s loyalty, Manchester United’s vision and Barcelona’s complete inability to stop spending explain a lot about the business of modern soccer.
content: Let’s try something different in this week’s newsletter: A journey through modern soccer in three (vaguely related) stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: The First Date That Lasted a Week
description: Before even leaving Jean Paul Broc Gomez’s Los Angeles apartment for dinner, Charlie Kelly knew he had met the one.
content: Charlie Kelly was so sure of a relationship with Jean Paul Broc Gomez that he began to think of ways to spend more time together before their first date officially got started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Neil
title: Boris Johnson Was Just Being Boris Johnson
description: Many hoped he would change. But that was never going to happen.
content: LONDON — I’ve always resisted comparisons between Boris Johnson and Donald Trump. Not anymore.

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Review Finds Agents Used Unnecessary Force Against Black Migrants
description: Four Border Patrol agents face discipline over the confrontation last year. But the 500-page report described deeper problems within the agency amid a crisis at the border.
content: WASHINGTON — Border Patrol agents on horseback used “unnecessary” force in September against Black migrants who crossed into Del Rio, Texas, en masse, amid a humanitarian crisis that exposed the Biden administration’s struggle to manage a record number of southwestern border crossings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Despite a Wimbledon Ban on Russian Players, a Russian Woman Might Win
description: Elena Rybakina was born and raised in Russia but started representing Kazakhstan after the Russian Tennis Federation gave up on her. Does she see herself as Russian? “It’s a tough question.”
content: WIMBLEDON, England — After all the debate over whether to bar Russian and Belarusian players from Wimbledon, and under pressure from the British government, the women’s singles title may be won on Saturday by a player born in Russia after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thessaly La Force
title: Being Marina Abramović, Even When No One’s Looking
description: Despite her success, the performance artist has chosen a monastic life in upstate New York, where she falls asleep to Canadian television and eats baby food.
content: The New York-based artist Marina Abramović is sitting in the kitchen of her house just outside of Hudson when she invites me — over FaceTime — to join her in Greece this August for a workshop organized by the Marina Abramović Institute (MAI). “It’s only five days. No food, no talking and heavy exercise,” says the artist, 75, with a chuckle. Abramović founded the institute in 2007, originally intending to convert a derelict theater built sometime around the 1930s nearby into a top-of-the-line Rem Koolhaas-designed performance space, archive and education center. But when the project’s budget ballooned out of her control (Koolhaas’s plans alone were estimated to be $31 million, which didn’t include the handling of the theater’s pre-existing asbestos problem) and her fund-raising efforts fell short (a Kickstarter only got her to a little over half a million dollars), Abramović decided to turn it into something that didn’t depend on a physical location. Its new slogan? “Don’t come to us; we come to you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Under Pressure, Biden Issues Executive Order on Abortion
description: After the Supreme Court’s ruling, some of the president’s supporters have wanted him to push harder to protect abortion access. But details about what his new order will do remain unclear.
content: WASHINGTON — Under pressure to do more to respond to the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, President Biden issued an executive order on Friday designed to ensure access to abortion medication and emergency contraception while preparing for legal fights to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘He Presented Another Path’: Actors and Directors on Peter Brook
description: Patrick Stewart, Tarell Alvin McCraney, Tina Landau and Tim Robbins on being challenged and inspired by the legendary theater maker, who died last weekend.
content: The actor Kathryn Hunter heard the news of the director Peter Brook’s death, last weekend at 97, in a telephone call from his longtime collaborator Marie-Hélène Estienne. Then Hunter, an Olivier Award winner who played the witches in Joel Coen’s film “The Tragedy of Macbeth,” set off across London for Shakespeare’s Globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Mauricio Lima
title: As Russia Looms, a Ukrainian City’s Loyalties Divide
description: Most residents have fled the eastern city of Sloviansk before an expected Russian assault. About half of the 23,000 remaining are eager to welcome the invaders.
content: SLOVIANSK, Ukraine — A woman berated visiting reporters, accusing them of publishing lies. Others turned away, reluctant to talk. Tensions were running high in the central market of Sloviansk, after rocket strikes earlier this week killed seven people and destroyed shops and houses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Mayor Who Never Sleeps
description: Is Eric Adams revealing himself to be the man the city needs?
content: On a breezy June night in the Bronx, I was on the balcony at the restaurant Zona De Cuba, sipping a mojito, vibing to a salsa band and peeking at a special menu for the plant-based mayor of New York, Eric Adams, who was soon to arrive.

title: Newly Published, From Banksy to Patrick Radden Keefe
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: BANKSY, by Stefano Antonelli and Gianluca Marziani. (Rizzoli Electa, $40.) This exhaustive collection showcases hundreds of works by the elusive street artist and global phenomenon, including famous paintings, serigraphs, stencils, installation objects and memorabilia.

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: A Bronx Tale of Persistence
description: Tara Cannistraci and Michael Mondrone, both natives of the borough, met five years ago at a Mexican restaurant in Scarsdale, N.Y. He asked her to stay. She said no. Twenty minutes later, he emailed. She returned.
content: Tara Cannistraci was finishing dinner with a friend at El Barrio in Scarsdale, N.Y., in early May 2017, when Michael Todd Mondrone, a part owner of the Mexican restaurant, sent over some sorbet as a way to introduce himself. “She thanked me on her way out,” Mr. Mondrone said. “I asked her to stay.”

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Air Pollution Kills 10 Million People a Year. Why Do We Accept That as Normal?
description: Threats often appear larger and more profound the farther off they are, and more manageable and even routine once they arrive
content: For every thousand people alive on earth, 973 are regularly inhaling toxins. Only 27 are not. Which means, almost certainly, you are too.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Blackall
title: Their Wildest Dreams
description: Two siblings, a playful teacher’s class and three friends let their imaginations loose in the great outdoors.
content: One summer, when I was a single mother raising my second and fourth graders in Brooklyn and the weeks ahead without child care loomed large, my friend Catherine and I rented a farmhouse in upstate New York for a month. She brought her 9-year-old twins, and we let the kids explore the woods while we worked. We gave them a loud whistle and generous boundaries — the distant stone wall, the serpentine stream, the neighboring field — and sent them off to run wild.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 911 Dispatcher Faces Manslaughter Charge After Failing to Send Ambulance
description: The authorities in Pennsylvania said the dispatcher told a woman that he would not send an ambulance to her mother unless the mother agreed to go to the hospital. She died the next day.
content: A 911 dispatcher has been charged with involuntary manslaughter after he failed to send an ambulance to a woman in rural Pennsylvania who was bleeding and incoherent and who died a day later, the authorities said.

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: These 8 measures reflect a slowing U.S. economy.

content: When Madelyn Elizabeth Krebs and Tyler Christopher Fox met in August 2013, she was starting her second year at the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics, a high school in Durham, and he was beginning his first.

title: What happens next for Brittney Griner?
description: The American basketball star still faces the conviction and sentencing phases of her trial in Russia. But experts say her best hope may be a diplomatic deal between the U.S. and Russia.
content: By pleading guilty to drug charges in a Russian courtroom this week, the American basketball star Brittney Griner has potentially accelerated her case’s conclusion, clearing a path for either a deal with the United States or, perhaps, a request for clemency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Private-sector employment has recovered to prepandemic levels.
description: Service businesses continue to climb back, but government payrolls are still short of February 2020 levels.
content: Job growth in June was driven by industries recuperating from pandemic-induced losses, and continued business investment in sectors still benefiting from formidable demand for their goods and services, even as borrowing costs increase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Will Reid, Carlos Prieto, Michael Simon Johnson, Rachelle Bonja, Chris Wood, Paige Cowett, Anita Badejo and Marion Lozano
title: The Final Days of Boris Johnson
description: He was famed for his ability to escape a political scandal. What brought down the British prime minister in the end?
content: After a flurry of ministerial resignations and calls from members of his own party for his departure, Boris Johnson agreed on Thursday to resign as prime minister of Britain.

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Trigger Point’ Review: Pure Pressure à la ‘Line of Duty’
description: A new Peacock series about a London bomb squad bears the mark of its showrunner, Jed Mercurio, Britain’s master of the crime melodrama.
content: There are two kinds of people in the world: those who haven’t seen or heard of the British cop show “Line of Duty” and those who are rabid fans of it. It isn’t a great television series, or even a very good one, necessarily. But it has a loony, breathless intensity that sucks you in and a willingness to toy with its regular characters’ emotions, and question their motives, that is dramatically suspect but melodramatically potent. Through six seasons, it remains one of Britain’s most popular and honored TV shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: You Can’t Outrun Athletic Greens
description: In the oversaturated world of wellness, the company has forced itself to the front with prolific podcast ads and a network of influencers.
content: Maybe you learned about Athletic Greens on an episode of “Pod Save America,” or between gruesome tales on “Crime Junkie.” Perhaps you heard an ad for it on Dax Shepard’s podcast, “Armchair Expert,” or Conan O’Brien’s or, if it’s more your style, Joe Rogan’s. title: Uniper, Germany’s largest gas importer, asks for government bailout.
description: Russian gas cutoffs are causing huge losses for the utility in the “middle double-digit million” euro area, Uniper’s chief executive said.
content: As Europe’s energy crisis escalates, Uniper, Germany’s largest importer of natural gas, asked the government for help on Friday, hours after Parliament passed a law aimed at keeping the energy provider afloat.

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Gun Violence Is Almost Nonexistent in Japan
description: The country has some of the most stringent laws around buying and owning a firearm.
content: The attack on former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan was especially shocking because it involved a gun — a type of crime that is extremely rare in a country with some of the most stringent laws around buying and owning a firearm.

author: By Gare Joyce
title: He’s the N.H.L.’s Next Big Star. He Just Has to Wait a Year.

In a departure from most drafts, no prospect had established himself as the best in his year and rumors and speculation swirled. The last time there had been any real suspense around the first overall pick dated back to the wooden-stick era.

content: TOKYO — Shinzo Abe, Japan’s most influential former prime minister, was stumping on behalf of a junior politician from his party near a train station in Japan’s old capital city of Nara on Friday morning when he collapsed, bleeding, on the street. He was shot in the neck, doctors said, by a gunman who later admitted he had come to kill him.

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Alan Arbesfeld branches out with a tricky cryptic challenge.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — Daily crossword solvers might recognize this puzzle’s constructor, Alan Arbesfeld, who has been making daily grids for The Times since 1981 — 131 in total, nearly all themed. This is his first variety puzzle and his first cryptic crossword. I love it: On one hand, there is something so mysterious and specialized about cryptics; they’re rare in the United States, and in their native stamping grounds of England their authors (or “setters”) often go by pseudonyms. On the other hand, what better source for a cryptic puzzle, full of puns and letter manipulation, than a mind that’s come up with puzzle themes by the dozen and pun entries by the hundreds? I like to think that this puzzle is composed of outtakes and oddities from all of those years of hard work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Johnson’s Lies Worked for Years, Until They Didn’t
description: The British prime minister thought he could swagger and dissemble his way through any scandal, but found the rules of gravity applied after all.
content: After a lifetime of swaggering and dissembling his way through one scandal after another on the strength of his prodigious political skills — a potent mix of charm, guile, ruthlessness, hubris, oratorical dexterity and rumpled Wodehousian bluster — Boris Johnson has finally reached the end. It seems that the laws of gravity apply to him after all.

content: LONDON — On a wall-mounted screen at the Museum of London, a low-resolution video showed young people rapping quickly and hungrily over syncopated beats. Every so often, a decidedly 2000s graphic flashed on the screen, reading “Risky Roadz 2.”

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: Remembering James Caan and His Potent Mix of Swagger and Delicacy
description: “The Godfather” helped open up a range of roles for the actor that allowed him to play against type and expectation in wonderful ways.
content: I’m not sure who owned the book, but eventually it ended up in my sweaty young hands. Someone at school had told me about the scene in Mario Puzo’s “The Godfather,” the one in which Sonny Corleone, the reckless eldest son with a Cupid face and a massive endowment, steals off with one of his sister’s bridesmaids. I remember racing through the passage (“her legs were wrapped around his thighs”). It’s no wonder that when I saw Francis Ford Coppola’s film, I was more than ready for James Caan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Bradley
title: The Historically Black College Reconsiders the Studio Art Program
description: After decades of being underfunded, H.B.C.U.s see an opportunity to expand their offerings and foster a new generation of artists.
content: The fourth edition of H. W. Janson’s “History of Art,” long the standard introductory text in art history courses, is over 850 pages long, with more than 1,000 illustrations, weighing in at over seven and a half pounds. It aims for the encyclopedic, “from cave paintings of the Old Stone Age to the latest video art.” During the fall of 1992, when the artist Derek Fordjour was 18 years old, he lugged the book to class at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn with earnest intentions of pursuing an artistic career. The child of Ghanaian immigrants who had made a home in Memphis, Fordjour had absorbed his parents’ work ethic and respect for education. But something was missing for him in that hefty tome: nearly the entire history of Black art in America.
source.name: The New York Times
